   obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq
   obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
 else
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
 endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation returns true if the this object and the 'other' reference are the same object ('this is other').

hash_code().Int32
Returns the hash code of this object, which some classes (like HashTable) rely on. This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

Hash codes are used to quickly test and see if two complex objects are NOT equal. The value returned has no intrinsic meaning, but should conform to the following rules:

1. Two objects that are equivalent should produce the same hash code.

2. If an object's state doesn't change, its hash code shouldn't change either. Internally, this precludes the hash code being based on an object's memory address since Slag doesn't guarantee that an object's address won't change over time.

This has the following implications:

If you override hash_code you should also override equals() and possibly compare_to() and ensure the following contract.

Invariant: 

  if (obj1.hash_code != obj2.hash_code)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

op%( DataType value ).DataType[]
Returns a list of the remainders of each of this object's values divided by the given value.

op%( Readable<<DataType>> values ).DataType[]
Returns a list of the remainders of each of this object's values divided by each of the corresponding given values.

op*( DataType value ).DataType[]
Multiplies the given value by each of this object's values and returns a list of the results.

op*( Readable<<DataType>> values ).DataType[]
Multiplies each of the given values by each of this object's corresponding values and returns a list of the results.

op+( Readable<<DataType>> values ).DataType[]
Adds each of the given values to each of this object's corresponding values and returns a list of the results.

op+( DataType value ).DataType[]
Adds the given value to each of this object's values and returns a list of the results.

op-( DataType value ).DataType[]
Subtracts the given value from each of this object's values and returns a list of the results.

op-().DataType[]
Returns a list containing the negative of each value in this object.

op-( Readable<<DataType>> values ).DataType[]
Subtracts each of the given values from each of this object's corresponding values and returns a list of the results.

op/( DataType value ).DataType[]
Divides each of this object's values by the given value and returns a list of the results.

op/( Readable<<DataType>> values ).DataType[]
Divides each of this object's values by each of the corresponding given values and returns a list of the results.

op^( DataType value ).DataType[]
Raises each of this object's values by the given value and returns a list of the results.

op^( Readable<<DataType>> values ).DataType[]
Raises each of this object's values by each of the corresponding given values and returns a list of the results.

product().DataType
Returns the product of all the values contained in this list-adaptable object.

sum().DataType
Returns the sum of all the values contained in this list-adaptable object.

to_String().String
Returns: 
  A String representation of this object.  Most classes
  should override this method to summarize an object's
  state for convenience in testing and debugging.

type_name().String
Returns the true class name of this object. Implemented by the runtime; you should not override this method.

Example: 

  local Object obj = "Hello World"
  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

ListAdaptableBitwise<<DataType>>

Aspect ListAdaptableBitwise<<DataType>>

Defines bitwise operations involving ListAdaptable types.

Class Methods
create_duplicate( Object existing ).Object
This factory method initiates object duplication. The compiler transforms the duplicate(obj) command into Object.create_duplicate(obj).

Returns: 

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

Object Methods
compare_to( Object other ).Ternary
This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

The compiler converts: 

  'obj1 < obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == lt'
  'obj1 > obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == gt'
  'obj1 <= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != gt'
  'obj1 >= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != lt'

    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  else
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
  endIf

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

 endIf

hash_code().Int32

Hash codes are used to quickly test and see if two complex objects are NOT equal. The value returned has no intrinsic meaning, but should conform to the following rules:

1. Two objects that are equivalent should produce the same hash code.

    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

op!().DataType[]
Returns a list containing the logical complement of each value in this object.

Only implemented for integer and Boolean ListAdaptable types.

op&( DataType value ).DataType[]
Performs a bitwise 'and' operation between each of this object's values and the given value and returns a list of results.

Only implemented for integer and Boolean ListAdaptable types.

op&( Readable<<DataType>> values ).DataType[]
Performs a bitwise 'and' operation between each of this object's values and each corresponding given value and returns a list of results.

Only implemented for integer and Boolean ListAdaptable types.

op|( DataType value ).DataType[]
Performs a bitwise 'or' operation between each of this object's values and the given value and returns a list of results.

Only implemented for integer and Boolean ListAdaptable types.

op|( Readable<<DataType>> values ).DataType[]
Performs a bitwise 'or' operation between each of this object's values and each corresponding given value and returns a list of results.

Only implemented for integer and Boolean ListAdaptable types.

op~( DataType value ).DataType[]
Performs a bitwise 'xor' operation between each of this object's values and the given value and returns a list of results.

Only implemented for integer and Boolean ListAdaptable types.

op~( Readable<<DataType>> values ).DataType[]
Performs a bitwise 'xor' operation between each of this object's values and each corresponding given value and returns a list of results.

Only implemented for integer and Boolean ListAdaptable types.

to_String().String
Returns: 
  A String representation of this object.  Most classes
  should override this method to summarize an object's
  state for convenience in testing and debugging.

type_name().String
Returns the true class name of this object. Implemented by the runtime; you should not override this method.

Example: 

  local Object obj = "Hello World"
  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

ListArithmetic<<DataType>>

Aspect ListArithmetic<<DataType>>

Defines arithmetic operations involving lists.

Class Methods
create_duplicate( Object existing ).Object
This factory method initiates object duplication. The compiler transforms the duplicate(obj) command into Object.create_duplicate(obj).

Returns: 

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

promote( DataType value ).DataType[]
When there is an operation of the form "DataType + List<<DataType>>" (where DataType is a primitive or compound), the compiler calls this method to promote the left-hand side operand to an object.

Object Methods
compare_to( Object other ).Ternary
This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

The compiler converts: 

  'obj1 < obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == lt'
  'obj1 > obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == gt'
  'obj1 <= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != gt'
  'obj1 >= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != lt'
Implementations of compare_to() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

  if (obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == true
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  else
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
  endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

compare_to( DataType value ).Ternary[]
Compares each of this list's values to the given value and returns a list of Ternary 'gt', 'lt', and 'eq' values.

Only implemented for numerical List types.

compare_to( Readable<<DataType>> values ).Ternary[]
Compares each of this list's values to each corresponding given value and returns a list of Ternary 'gt', 'lt', and 'eq' values.

Only implemented for numerical List types.

create_duplicate().Object
Should create a duplicate of this object such that obj1.equals(obj1.create_duplicate) return true.

The command duplicate(obj) is transformed by the compiler into Object.create_duplicate(obj), which then calls this method.

For optimal performance (by removing an internal typecast in most situations), have your overridden create_duplicate have the same return type as the class it's defined in. For instance, Strings implementation is 'create_duplicate.String'.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

equals( Object other ).Boolean
Returns true if this object is equivalant to another.

The compiler converts 'obj1 == obj2' into 'obj1.equals(obj2)' and 'obj1 != obj2' into 'not obj1.equals(obj2)'.

Implementations of equals() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

 if (obj1.equals(obj2))
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq
   obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
 else
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
 endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation returns true if the this object and the 'other' reference are the same object ('this is other').

hash_code().Int32
Returns the hash code of this object, which some classes (like HashTable) rely on. This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

Hash codes are used to quickly test and see if two complex objects are NOT equal. The value returned has no intrinsic meaning, but should conform to the following rules:

1. Two objects that are equivalent should produce the same hash code.

2. If an object's state doesn't change, its hash code shouldn't change either. Internally, this precludes the hash code being based on an object's memory address since Slag doesn't guarantee that an object's address won't change over time.

This has the following implications:

If you override hash_code you should also override equals() and possibly compare_to() and ensure the following contract.

Invariant: 

  if (obj1.hash_code != obj2.hash_code)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

op%( Readable<<DataType>> values ).DataType[]
Returns a list of the remainders of each of this list's values divided by each of the corresponding given values.

Only implemented for numerical List types.

op%( DataType value ).DataType[]
Returns a list of the remainders of each of this list's values divided by the given value.

Only implemented for numerical List types.

op*( DataType value ).DataType[]
Multiplies the given value by each of this list's values and returns a list of the results.

Only implemented for numerical List types.

op*( Readable<<DataType>> values ).DataType[]
Multiplies each given value by each of this list's corresponding values and returns a list of the results.

Only implemented for numerical List types.

op+( DataType value ).DataType[]
Adds the given value to each of this list's values and returns a list of the results.

Only implemented for numerical List types.

op+( Readable<<DataType>> values ).DataType[]
Adds each given value to each of this list's corresponding values and returns a list of the results.

Only implemented for numerical List types.

op-( DataType value ).DataType[]
Subtracts the given value from each of this list's values and returns a list of the results.

Only implemented for numerical List types.

op-().DataType[]
Returns a list containing the negative of each value in this list.

Only implemented for numerical List types.

op-( Readable<<DataType>> values ).DataType[]
Subtracts each given value from each of this list's corresponding values and returns a list of the results.

Only implemented for numerical List types.

op/( Readable<<DataType>> values ).DataType[]
Divides each of this list's values by each corresponding given value and returns a list of the results.

Only implemented for numerical List types.

op/( DataType value ).DataType[]
Divides each of this list's values by the given value and returns a list of the results.

Only implemented for numerical List types.

op^( DataType value ).DataType[]
Raises each of this list's values to the power of the given value and returns a list of the results.

Only implemented for numerical List types.

op^( Readable<<DataType>> values ).DataType[]
Raises each of this list's values to the power of each corresponding given value and returns a list of the results.

Only implemented for numerical List types.

product().DataType
Returns the product of all the values contained in this list-adaptable object.

Only implemented for numerical list types.

sort( [SORT order] )
Sorts this list in place using a HeapSort. 'order' is SORT.ascending by default.

Only implemented for numerical and String lists. To enable it for lists of other types (say, Event), add this augment: 

  augment List<<Event>>
    METHODS
      method sort( SORT order=SORT.ascending ):
        HeapSort<<DataType>>.sort( this, order )
  endAugment

sorted( [SORT order] ).List<<DataType>>
Returns an list containing the elements of this data sorted into order. Only implemented for numerical and String lists.

sum().DataType
Returns the sum of all the values contained in this list-adaptable object.

Only implemented for numerical list types.

to_String().String
Returns: 
  A String representation of this object.  Most classes
  should override this method to summarize an object's
  state for convenience in testing and debugging.

type_name().String
Returns the true class name of this object. Implemented by the runtime; you should not override this method.

Example: 

  local Object obj = "Hello World"
  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

The compiler converts:

  'obj1 > obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == gt'
  'obj1 <= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != gt'
  'obj1 >= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != lt'

Contract:

    obj1.equals(obj2) == true
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  else
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
  endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

hash_code().Int32
Returns the hash code of this object, which some classes (like HashTable) rely on. This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

Hash codes are used to quickly test and see if two complex objects are NOT equal. The value returned has no intrinsic meaning, but should conform to the following rules:

1. Two objects that are equivalent should produce the same hash code.

2. If an object's state doesn't change, its hash code shouldn't change either. Internally, this precludes the hash code being based on an object's memory address since Slag doesn't guarantee that an object's address won't change over time.

This has the following implications:

Invariant:

    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

op!().DataType[]
Returns a list containing the logical complement of each value in this list.

Only implemented for integer and Boolean List types.

Performs a bitwise 'and' operation between each of this list's values and the given value and returns a list of results.

  'obj1 <= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != gt'
  'obj1 >= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != lt'

Hash codes are used to quickly test and see if two complex objects are NOT equal. The value returned has no intrinsic meaning, but should conform to the following rules:

  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

chain_next( PatternMatcher _next )
compare_to( Object other ).Ternary
This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

LookaheadReader<<DataType>>

Class LookaheadReader<<DataType>>

: Reader<<DataType>>

Wraps an existing reader and can peek more than one value ahead.

peek(1) is equivalent to peek(); peek(n) reads 'n' values ahead.

Example: 

  local LookaheadReader<<Int32>> range(1..10)
  println( range.read )     #prints: 1
  println( range.peek )     #prints: 2
  println( range.peek(2) )  #prints: 3
  println( range.peek(4) )  #prints: 5
  println( range.read )     #prints: 2
  println( range.peek(2) )  #prints: 4

Class Methods
create_duplicate( Object existing ).Object
This factory method initiates object duplication. The compiler transforms the duplicate(obj) command into Object.create_duplicate(obj).

Returns: 

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

Object Variables
input_queue : DataType[]
Internal use - buffer of values read in while peeking.

src : Reader<<DataType>>
The backing source of values for this LookaheadReader.

Object Methods
available().Int32
Returns the minimum number of additional values that can be immediately read from this reader.

If the reader is exhausted or if it must block to peek or read next then the result will be 0. It is important to note that '0' does not necessarily mean the reader is exhausted.

Many readers will report that they have 1 available even if there are thousands of values waiting to be read. The 'available' property should be used as an aide for buffer sizes and the like but should not be taken as an absolute size.

close()
Closes this reader as a source of input. Useful for file readers, but for most others this command does nothing.

compare_to( Object other ).Ternary
This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

The compiler converts: 

  'obj1 < obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == lt'
  'obj1 > obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == gt'
  'obj1 <= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != gt'
  'obj1 >= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != lt'
Implementations of compare_to() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

  if (obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == true
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  else
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
  endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

consume( DataType look_for ).Boolean
Attempts to match and discard the next value from this reader, returning true, or else leaves the next value still pending and returns false.

Returns: 

  "true" if old.peek == look_for
  "false" if old.peek != look_for
Invariant: 
  if (old.peek == look_for) old.skip

consume( String sequence ).Boolean
Attempts to read and discard the given string. Returns "true" and discards the entire string on success or returns "false" and discards nothing on failure.

Only defined for LookaheadReader<<Char>>.

create_duplicate().Object
Should create a duplicate of this object such that obj1.equals(obj1.create_duplicate) return true.

The command duplicate(obj) is transformed by the compiler into Object.create_duplicate(obj), which then calls this method.

For optimal performance (by removing an internal typecast in most situations), have your overridden create_duplicate have the same return type as the class it's defined in. For instance, Strings implementation is 'create_duplicate.String'.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

discard_spaces().Boolean
Discards any number of spaces that come next in the input.

Returns "true" if at least one space was discarded or "false" if not.

Only defined for LookaheadReader<<Char>>.

equals( Object other ).Boolean
Returns true if this object is equivalant to another.

The compiler converts 'obj1 == obj2' into 'obj1.equals(obj2)' and 'obj1 != obj2' into 'not obj1.equals(obj2)'.

Implementations of equals() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

 if (obj1.equals(obj2))
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq
   obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
 else
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
 endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation returns true if the this object and the 'other' reference are the same object ('this is other').

has_another( Int32 reads_ahead ).Boolean
Returns "true" if this reader has at least 'reads_ahead' more values that can be previewed with peek() or read with read().

has_another().Boolean
Returns "true" if this reader has another value that can be previewed with peek() or read with read().

hash_code().Int32
Returns the hash code of this object, which some classes (like HashTable) rely on. This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

Hash codes are used to quickly test and see if two complex objects are NOT equal. The value returned has no intrinsic meaning, but should conform to the following rules:

1. Two objects that are equivalent should produce the same hash code.

2. If an object's state doesn't change, its hash code shouldn't change either. Internally, this precludes the hash code being based on an object's memory address since Slag doesn't guarantee that an object's address won't change over time.

This has the following implications:

If you override hash_code you should also override equals() and possibly compare_to() and ensure the following contract.

Invariant: 

  if (obj1.hash_code != obj2.hash_code)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

init( Readable<<DataType>> readable )
Initializes this LookaheadReader to read from the given readable character data.

init( Reader<<DataType>> src )
Initializes this LookaheadReader to read from the given reader.

is_exhausted().Boolean
Returns "true" if this reader does not have another value or "false" if it does.

peek( Int32 reads_ahead ).DataType
Returns the value that will be returned after 'reads_ahead' more reads.

peek().DataType
Returns the next value that will be returned from read(). If there is no next value then a NoNextValueError is thrown.

position( Int32 new_position )
This optional property-write sets the zero-based read position of this reader. When a reader is first created position() returns 0. After a single read() it returns 1, and so on. Readers that don't implement this property will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

position().Int32
This optional property-read returns the zero-based read position of this reader. When a reader is first created position() returns 0. After a single read() it returns 1, and so on.

Readers that don't implement this property will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

read().DataType
Returns the next value from this reader. If (not has_another) then a NoNextValueError is thrown.

read_line().String
Reads and returns the next line of characters up to the next LF or CRLF. The CRLF characters are not part of the return value and are discarded.

Only defined for Reader<<Char>>.

read_list( Int32 size ).DataType[]
Reads the next 'size' number of values and returns them in a list. Requires that there are at least 'size' number of values remaining to be read.

remaining().Int32
This optional property returns how many values remain to be read before the reader is exhausted. Not all readers can implement this property; those that don't will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

rewind()
This optional method resets this reader so that the next read() will return the first value of the series. Readers that don't implement this property will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

skip( [Int32 skip_count] )
Discards exactly the next 'skip_count' number of values rather than reading them. If there are not enough values remaining then a NoNextValueError will be thrown from read().

This program fragment: 

  local var a = reader.read
  reader.read
  reader.read
  local var b = reader.read
is equivalent to this: 
  local var a = reader.read
  reader.skip(2)
  local var b = reader.read

to_List().DataType[]
Creates and returns a list of all the remaining values of this reader.

to_String().String
Returns a string representation of this reader's values.

type_name().String
Returns the true class name of this object. Implemented by the runtime; you should not override this method.

Example: 

  local Object obj = "Hello World"
  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

LookupTable<<KeyType,ValueType>>

Class LookupTable<<KeyType,ValueType>>

Base class for all variants of a lookup table - Slag's version of the dictionary or map. See HashTable.

Class Methods
create_duplicate( Object existing ).Object
This factory method initiates object duplication. The compiler transforms the duplicate(obj) command into Object.create_duplicate(obj).

Returns: 

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

Object Methods
compare_to( Object other ).Ternary
This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

The compiler converts: 

  'obj1 < obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == lt'
  'obj1 > obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == gt'
  'obj1 <= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != gt'
  'obj1 >= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != lt'
Implementations of compare_to() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

  if (obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == true
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  else
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
  endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

contains( KeyType key ).Boolean
Returns "true" if 'key' has an associated value in this table that can be retrieved with get().

count().Int32
Returns the number of mappings in this table.

create_duplicate().Object
Should create a duplicate of this object such that obj1.equals(obj1.create_duplicate) return true.

The command duplicate(obj) is transformed by the compiler into Object.create_duplicate(obj), which then calls this method.

For optimal performance (by removing an internal typecast in most situations), have your overridden create_duplicate have the same return type as the class it's defined in. For instance, Strings implementation is 'create_duplicate.String'.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

equals( Object other ).Boolean
Returns true if this object is equivalant to another.

The compiler converts 'obj1 == obj2' into 'obj1.equals(obj2)' and 'obj1 != obj2' into 'not obj1.equals(obj2)'.

Implementations of equals() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

 if (obj1.equals(obj2))
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq
   obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
 else
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
 endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation returns true if the this object and the 'other' reference are the same object ('this is other').

find( KeyType key ).Mapping<<KeyType,ValueType>>
Finds the underlying Mapping that defines the mapping between 'key' and 'value'. Returns a null reference if no mapping is present. Useful for optimizing conditional table operations.

Example without find(): 

  if (table.contains(id))
    person = table[id]
  endIf
Example with find() - a bit faster: 
  local var mapping = table.find(id)
  if (mapping isNot null)
    person = mapping.value
  endIf

get( KeyType key ).ValueType
Retrieves the value (previously mapped with set()) associated with 'key'. Throws a NoSuchElementError if 'key' has not been defined.

hash_code().Int32
Returns the hash code of this object, which some classes (like HashTable) rely on. This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

Hash codes are used to quickly test and see if two complex objects are NOT equal. The value returned has no intrinsic meaning, but should conform to the following rules:

1. Two objects that are equivalent should produce the same hash code.

2. If an object's state doesn't change, its hash code shouldn't change either. Internally, this precludes the hash code being based on an object's memory address since Slag doesn't guarantee that an object's address won't change over time.

This has the following implications:

If you override hash_code you should also override equals() and possibly compare_to() and ensure the following contract.

Invariant: 

  if (obj1.hash_code != obj2.hash_code)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

remove( KeyType key ).ValueType
Removes the mapping between 'key' and its value from this table. Throws a NoSuchElementError if 'key' has not been defined.

set( KeyType key, ValueType value )
Associates the given value with the given key. When get() is called with 'key', 'value' will be returned.

to_String().String
Returns: 
  A String representation of this object.  Most classes
  should override this method to summarize an object's
  state for convenience in testing and debugging.

type_name().String
Returns the true class name of this object. Implemented by the runtime; you should not override this method.

Example: 

  local Object obj = "Hello World"
  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

Mapping<<KeyType,ValueType>>

Class Mapping<<KeyType,ValueType>>

Associates a key with a value. Used in LookupTable classes.

Class Methods
create_duplicate( Object existing ).Object
This factory method initiates object duplication. The compiler transforms the duplicate(obj) command into Object.create_duplicate(obj).

Returns: 

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

Object Variables
key : KeyType
value : ValueType

Object Methods
compare_to( Object other ).Ternary
This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

The compiler converts: 

  'obj1 < obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == lt'
  'obj1 > obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == gt'
  'obj1 <= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != gt'
  'obj1 >= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != lt'

  else
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
  endIf

1. Two objects that are equivalent should produce the same hash code.

2. If an object's state doesn't change, its hash code shouldn't change either. Internally, this precludes the hash code being based on an object's memory address since Slag doesn't guarantee that an object's address won't change over time.

This has the following implications:

If you override hash_code you should also override equals() and possibly compare_to() and ensure the following contract.

Invariant:

    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

init( KeyType key, ValueType value )

Returns: 
  A String representation of this object.  Most classes
  should override this method to summarize an object's
  state for convenience in testing and debugging.

type_name().String
Returns the true class name of this object. Implemented by the runtime; you should not override this method.

Example: 

  local Object obj = "Hello World"
  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

MissingReturnError

Class MissingReturnError

: Error

The Slag VM program loader appends a 'throw MissingReturnError()' command to the end of every method. If the programmer forgets or if an exploit omits the 'return' value then the program will fail with an exception once it reaches that point.

Class Methods
create_duplicate( Object existing ).Object
This factory method initiates object duplication. The compiler transforms the duplicate(obj) command into Object.create_duplicate(obj).

Returns: 

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

Object Variables
ip : Int64
The execution ip at the time of the exception. If generated by Slag code this is "manually" calculated (as in 'Global.excecution_ip(-2)') or by the runtime environment if generated by the VM or runtime.

message : String
The error message.

Object Methods
compare_to( Object other ).Ternary
This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

init()
Sets the error message to an empty string.

  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

MouseDispatcher

Aspect MouseDispatcher

: DispatcherType

Class Methods

This factory method initiates object duplication. The compiler transforms the duplicate(obj) command into Object.create_duplicate(obj).

Returns: 

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

Object Methods
add_mouse_listener( MouseListener listener )
Registers the given MouseListener so that it receives any mouse events that this dispatcher sends.

compare_to( Object other ).Ternary
This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

  'obj1 < obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == lt'
  'obj1 > obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == gt'

  'obj1 >= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != lt'

dispatch_mouse_absent()
Sends the given mouse presence event to all registered listeners.

dispatch_mouse_button_press( MouseEvent event )
Sends the given mouse button press event to all registered listeners.

dispatch_mouse_button_release( MouseEvent event )
Sends the given mouse button release event to all registered listeners.

dispatch_mouse_movement( MouseEvent event )
Sends the given mouse movement event to all registered listeners.

dispatch_mouse_position( MouseEvent event )
Sends the given mouse position event to all registered listeners.

dispatch_mouse_present()
Sends the given mouse presence event to all registered listeners.

dispatch_mouse_wheel_down( MouseEvent event )
Sends the given mouse wheel event to all registered listeners.

dispatch_mouse_wheel_up( MouseEvent event )
Sends the given mouse wheel event to all registered listeners.

equals( Object other ).Boolean
Returns true if this object is equivalant to another.

The compiler converts 'obj1 == obj2' into 'obj1.equals(obj2)' and 'obj1 != obj2' into 'not obj1.equals(obj2)'.

   obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq

 else

 endIf

  endIf

    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

Returns the list of mouse listeners registered with this mouse dispatcher.

remove_mouse_listener( MouseListener listener )
Removes the given MouseListener so that it no longer receives any mouse events from this dispatcher.

MouseEvent

Compound MouseEvent ( Vector2 position, Int32 button )

Contains information about a given mouse event. The type of event is determined by the method the event is received in - on_mouse_position(), on_mouse_movement(), etc.

Parameters: 

  position
    The mouse position at the time of the mouse event.

  button
    The mouse button that was pressed for appropriate events.

MouseEvent-related methods in class Global

Composite Elements
position : Vector2
button : Int32

MouseListener

Aspect MouseListener

Defines the methods of a MouseListener that receives mouse events.

Class Methods
create_duplicate( Object existing ).Object
This factory method initiates object duplication. The compiler transforms the duplicate(obj) command into Object.create_duplicate(obj).

Returns: 

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

equals( Object other ).Boolean
Returns true if this object is equivalant to another.

The compiler converts 'obj1 == obj2' into 'obj1.equals(obj2)' and 'obj1 != obj2' into 'not obj1.equals(obj2)'.

Implementations of equals() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

 if (obj1.equals(obj2))
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq
   obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
 else
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
 endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation returns true if the this object and the 'other' reference are the same object ('this is other').

hash_code().Int32
Returns the hash code of this object, which some classes (like HashTable) rely on. This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

Hash codes are used to quickly test and see if two complex objects are NOT equal. The value returned has no intrinsic meaning, but should conform to the following rules:

1. Two objects that are equivalent should produce the same hash code.

2. If an object's state doesn't change, its hash code shouldn't change either. Internally, this precludes the hash code being based on an object's memory address since Slag doesn't guarantee that an object's address won't change over time.

This has the following implications:

If you override hash_code you should also override equals() and possibly compare_to() and ensure the following contract.

Invariant: 

  if (obj1.hash_code != obj2.hash_code)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

listen_to( DispatcherType dispatcher )
Instructs this MouseListener to listen to the given dispatcher.

on_mouse_absent()
Called when the the game window loses mouse focus.

on_mouse_button_press( MouseEvent event )
Called when a mouse button has been pressed.

'event.button' contains the index of the mouse button being pressed (1=left, 2=right).

'event.position' contains the absolute mouse position at the time of the press.

on_mouse_button_release( MouseEvent event )
Called when a mouse button has been pressed.

'event.button' contains the index of the mouse button being pressed (1=left, 2=right).

'event.position' contains the absolute mouse position at the time of the press.

on_mouse_movement( MouseEvent event )
Called when the mouse position changes. 'event' contains the new mouse position in relative (delta) coordinates.

on_mouse_position() is also called with the new absolute position.

on_mouse_position( MouseEvent event )
Called when the mouse position changes. 'event' contains the new mouse position in absolute coordinates.

on_mouse_movement() is also called with the relative position change.

on_mouse_present()
Called when the mouse focus returns to the game window after being elsewhere.

on_mouse_wheel_down( MouseEvent event )
Called when the mouse wheel has been rotated one click down.

'event.position' contains the absolute mouse position at the time of the wheel movement.

on_mouse_wheel_up( MouseEvent event )
Called when the mouse wheel has been rotated one click up.

'event.position' contains the absolute mouse position at the time of the wheel movement.

stop_listening_to( DispatcherType dispatcher )
Stops this MouseListener from listening to the given dispatcher.

to_String().String
Returns: 
  A String representation of this object.  Most classes
  should override this method to summarize an object's
  state for convenience in testing and debugging.

type_name().String
Returns the true class name of this object. Implemented by the runtime; you should not override this method.

Example: 

  local Object obj = "Hello World"
  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

NativeAudio

Class NativeAudio

Native layer interface for audio. Programmers are encouraged to use the higher-level class "Sound" instead, with the one exception being the audio_supported() method.

Class Methods
Sound_duplicate( Int32 existing_index ).Int32
Creates a duplicate of the existing sound that can be played and paused (etc.) independently of the original sound. Requires minimal additional resources.

Sound_get_position( Int32 sound_index ).Int32
Returns the playback sample index of the given sound.

Sound_is_playing( Int32 sound_index ).Boolean
Returns "true" if the given sound is currently playing or "false" if's paused or finished.

Sound_load( String filename, [Ternary decode] ).Int32
Loads a sound from the given file and returns the index that can be used to reference it.

Parameters: 

  filename
    The file to be loaded.

    The following variations of 'filename' are checked:

      filename
      filename.ext  (.ext = [.ogg|.wav|.flac|.mod|.aiff])
      data/filename
      data/filename.ext

  decode
    yes
      File is loaded into memory and decoded into raw PCM
      samples.  Requires more memory but less processor time
      when playing.

    no
      File is loaded into memory in its original
      compressed/encoded format.  Requires less memory but
      more processor time when playing.

    void
      The system determines whether to decompress the file
      or not.  For PC and Mac, files less than 20K in size
      are decoded and larger ones are not.

Sound_pause( Int32 sound_index )
Pauses playback of the given sound.

Sound_play( Int32 sound_index )
Plays the given sound from where it was paused or from the beginning from the beginning if it has completed playing.

Sound_release( Int32 sound_index )
Releases the sound with the given index; if there are no more references to that sound data then it's freed.

Sound_set_pan( Int32 sound_index, Real64 pan )
Sets the playback to be anywhere from left speaker only (-1.0) to right speaker only (1.0). Both speakers evenly is 0.0.

Sound_set_pitch_shift( Int32 sound_index, Real64 shift )
Increases or decreases the pitch of the sound. 1.0 is normal pitch; 2.0 is twice the pitch and 0.5 is half the pitch.

Sound_set_position( Int32 sound_index, Int32 new_position )
Sets the playback sample position to the given position.

Sound_set_repeat( Int32 sound_index, Boolean setting )
Sets the given sound to repeat (or not) after it finishes playing.

Sound_set_volume( Int32 sound_index, Real64 volume )
Sets the volume of the given sound. 1.0 is normal volume, 0.0 is silence.

audio_supported().Boolean
Returns "true" if the computer running this application has standard audio support. If "false" the implication is that each attempt at loading a sound will fail with a FileError.

create_duplicate( Object existing ).Object
This factory method initiates object duplication. The compiler transforms the duplicate(obj) command into Object.create_duplicate(obj).

Returns: 

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

Object Methods
compare_to( Object other ).Ternary
This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

The compiler converts: 

  'obj1 < obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == lt'
  'obj1 > obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == gt'
  'obj1 <= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != gt'
  'obj1 >= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != lt'
Implementations of compare_to() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

  if (obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == true
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  else
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
  endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

create_duplicate().Object
Should create a duplicate of this object such that obj1.equals(obj1.create_duplicate) return true.

The command duplicate(obj) is transformed by the compiler into Object.create_duplicate(obj), which then calls this method.

For optimal performance (by removing an internal typecast in most situations), have your overridden create_duplicate have the same return type as the class it's defined in. For instance, Strings implementation is 'create_duplicate.String'.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

equals( Object other ).Boolean
Returns true if this object is equivalant to another.

The compiler converts 'obj1 == obj2' into 'obj1.equals(obj2)' and 'obj1 != obj2' into 'not obj1.equals(obj2)'.

Implementations of equals() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

 if (obj1.equals(obj2))
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq
   obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
 else
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
 endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation returns true if the this object and the 'other' reference are the same object ('this is other').

hash_code().Int32
Returns the hash code of this object, which some classes (like HashTable) rely on. This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

Hash codes are used to quickly test and see if two complex objects are NOT equal. The value returned has no intrinsic meaning, but should conform to the following rules:

1. Two objects that are equivalent should produce the same hash code.

2. If an object's state doesn't change, its hash code shouldn't change either. Internally, this precludes the hash code being based on an object's memory address since Slag doesn't guarantee that an object's address won't change over time.

This has the following implications:

If you override hash_code you should also override equals() and possibly compare_to() and ensure the following contract.

Invariant: 

  if (obj1.hash_code != obj2.hash_code)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

to_String().String
Returns: 
  A String representation of this object.  Most classes
  should override this method to summarize an object's
  state for convenience in testing and debugging.

type_name().String
Returns the true class name of this object. Implemented by the runtime; you should not override this method.

Example: 

  local Object obj = "Hello World"
  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

NativeGraphics

Class NativeGraphics

Slagcore graphics primitives. In general do not call directly as you won't get the benefit of the origin transformation.

Class Methods
create_duplicate( Object existing ).Object
This factory method initiates object duplication. The compiler transforms the duplicate(obj) command into Object.create_duplicate(obj).

Returns: 

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

create_image( Bitmap bitmap, Int32 pixel_format ).Int32
Creates a hardware-accelerated image from the given software Bitmap.

'pixel_format' is one of the flag values defined in PIXEL_FORMAT.

Returns: 

  The index the native layer uses to track the image.  The
  value "0" indicates that an error occurred.

create_image( Int32 src_index, Int32 x, Int32 y, Int32 w, Int32 h ).Int32
Internal use.

Defines an image that's a subset of an existing image from top-left corner (x,y) and (w,h) pixels in size. Does not use any additional texture memory.

draw_image( Int32 image_index, Real64 xa, Real64 ya, Real64 xb, Real64 yb, Real64 xc, Real64 yc, Real64 xd, Real64 yd, Color color1, Color color2, Color color3, Color color4, Int32 render_flags )
Internal use.

Draws a quadrangle textured with the given image and having given color multipliers.

'render_flags' can be any of the RENDER constants.

draw_line( Real64 x1, Real64 y1, Real64 x2, Real64 y2, Color color, Int32 render_flags )
Internal use.

Draws a line from (x1,y1) to (x2,y2) in the specified color (alpha values used).

'render_flags' can be any of the RENDER constants.

draw_point( Real64 x, Real64 y, Color color, Int32 render_flags )
Internal use.

Draws a single point at screen location (x,y) in the specified color.

'render_flags' can be any of the RENDER constants.

fill_quad( Real64 x1, Real64 y1, Real64 x2, Real64 y2, Real64 x3, Real64 y3, Real64 x4, Real64 y4, Color color1, Color color2, Color color3, Color color4, Int32 render_flags )
Internal use.

Draws a sold-filled quadrangle with the specified corners and corner colors. The alpha values of the colors are used.

'render_flags' can be any of the RENDER constants.

get_image_height( Int32 image_index ).Int32
Internal use.

Returns the nominal pixel height (texel height) of the given image.

get_image_width( Int32 image_index ).Int32
Internal use.

Returns the nominal pixel width (texel width) of the given image.

get_uv( Int32 image_index ).Corners
Internal use.

Returns the (u,v) coordinate pairs for the top-left and bottom right of the given image.

is_fullscreen().Boolean
Returns "true" if the application is running in fullscreen mode or "false" if it's running in windowed mode. Use set_fullscreen() to change it.

load_bitmap( String filename ).Bitmap
Internal use.

Loads the given png or jpg image with the given filename.

Returns null if file not found or error loading.

load_image( String filename, Int32 pixel_format ).Int32
Internal use.

The following variations of 'filename' are checked: 

  filename
  filename.ext  (.ext = [.png|.jpg|.jpeg])
  data/filename
  data/filename.ext
Loads the given png or jpg image with the given filename and returns the index the native layer uses to track the image (0 indicates error).

'pixel_format' is one of the flag values defined in PIXEL_FORMAT.

release_image( Int32 image_index )
Releases the hardware image associated with the given image_index.

set_alpha_source( Int32 image_index, Int32 alpha_src_image_index )
Internal use.

Sets the given image to its colors but the alpha of the other given image.

set_fullscreen( Boolean setting )
Sets the application to fullscreen if setting is "true" or windowed mode if it's "false". Use is_fullscreen() to detect the current mode.

set_image( Int32 image_index, Bitmap new_bitmap )
Copies the pixel data from 'new_bitmap' into the hardware-accelerated image at the given index. Useful for dynamically-generated bitmaps and more efficient than calling create_image(Bitmap) repeatedly.

Note: the resulting image is always in rgb32 format.

set_uv( Int32 image_index, Corners corners )
Internal use.

Sets the (u,v) coordinate pairs for the top-left and bottom right of the given image.

set_viewport( Real64 x, Real64 y, Real64 width, Real64 height )
Sets the viewport borders to the top-left pixel position (x,y) with the given pixel width and height.

Object Methods
compare_to( Object other ).Ternary
This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

The compiler converts: 

  'obj1 < obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == lt'
  'obj1 > obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == gt'
  'obj1 <= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != gt'
  'obj1 >= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != lt'
Implementations of compare_to() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

  if (obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == true
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  else
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
  endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

create_duplicate().Object
Should create a duplicate of this object such that obj1.equals(obj1.create_duplicate) return true.

The command duplicate(obj) is transformed by the compiler into Object.create_duplicate(obj), which then calls this method.

For optimal performance (by removing an internal typecast in most situations), have your overridden create_duplicate have the same return type as the class it's defined in. For instance, Strings implementation is 'create_duplicate.String'.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

Returns true if this object is equivalant to another.

The compiler converts 'obj1 == obj2' into 'obj1.equals(obj2)' and 'obj1 != obj2' into 'not obj1.equals(obj2)'.

Implementations of equals() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract:

   obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq
   obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
 else
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
 endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation returns true if the this object and the 'other' reference are the same object ('this is other').

hash_code().Int32
Returns the hash code of this object, which some classes (like HashTable) rely on. This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

Hash codes are used to quickly test and see if two complex objects are NOT equal. The value returned has no intrinsic meaning, but should conform to the following rules:

1. Two objects that are equivalent should produce the same hash code.

2. If an object's state doesn't change, its hash code shouldn't change either. Internally, this precludes the hash code being based on an object's memory address since Slag doesn't guarantee that an object's address won't change over time.

This has the following implications:

Invariant:

    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

to_String().String
Returns: 
  A String representation of this object.  Most classes
  should override this method to summarize an object's
  state for convenience in testing and debugging.

type_name().String
Returns the true class name of this object. Implemented by the runtime; you should not override this method.

Example: 

  local Object obj = "Hello World"
  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

NativeInput

Class NativeInput

: KeyDispatcherProxy, MouseDispatcherProxy, JoystickDispatcherProxy, RequiresCleanup

Manages application input.

Class Variables
first_repeat_delay_in_ticks : Int32
Internal use.

next_repeat_delay_in_ticks : Int32
Internal use.

Class Methods
create_duplicate( Object existing ).Object
This factory method initiates object duplication. The compiler transforms the duplicate(obj) command into Object.create_duplicate(obj).

Returns: 

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

Object Variables
application : Application
A reference to the Plasmacore application - set by the application itself.

joystick_connected : Boolean[]
True if a given joystick 0..3 is detected and able to provide input.

joystick_dispatcher : JoystickDispatcher
The actual joystick dispatcher that this object is a proxy for.

key_dispatcher : KeyDispatcher
The actual key dispatcher that this object is a proxy for.

key_modifiers : Int32
The set of flags representing which SHIFT, ALT, and CTRL key modifiers are currently pressed. Most applications will want to call one of these methods instead: 

  shift_pressed()
  ctrl_pressed()
  alt_pressed()
  caps_locked()

key_repeat_delay_in_ticks : Int32
Internal use - a countdown until a pressed key repeats.

key_state : Boolean[]
"true" if the given raw keycode (e.g. KEY.keycode_a) is currently pressed, "false" if not.

last_key_pressed : Int32
Internal use - used for key repeating.

mouse_button_state : Array<<Boolean>>
mouse_button_state[i] (where i is 1 to 9) is "true" if that mouse button is currently pressed.

mouse_dispatcher : MouseDispatcher
The actual mouse dispatcher that this object is a proxy for.

mouse_position : Vector2
The current mouse position.

mouse_present : Boolean
"true" if this application has the mouse focus.

Object Methods
add_joystick_listener( JoystickListener listener )
Registers the given JoystickListener so that it receives any joystick events that this dispatcher sends.

add_key_listener( KeyListener listener )
Registers the given KeyListener so that it receives any key events that this dispatcher sends.

add_mouse_listener( MouseListener listener )
Registers the given MouseListener so that it receives any mouse events that this dispatcher sends.

alt_pressed().Boolean
Returns "true" if either of the alt keys is currently pressed.

alt_pressed( Boolean setting )
Internal use - alt_pressed property-set.

caps_locked( Boolean setting )
Internal use - caps_locked property-set.

caps_locked().Boolean
Returns "true" if CAPS LOCK is on.

clean_up()
Called automatically.

compare_to( Object other ).Ternary
This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

The compiler converts: 

  'obj1 < obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == lt'
  'obj1 > obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == gt'
  'obj1 <= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != gt'
  'obj1 >= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != lt'
Implementations of compare_to() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

  if (obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == true
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  else
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
  endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

create_duplicate().Object
Should create a duplicate of this object such that obj1.equals(obj1.create_duplicate) return true.

The command duplicate(obj) is transformed by the compiler into Object.create_duplicate(obj), which then calls this method.

For optimal performance (by removing an internal typecast in most situations), have your overridden create_duplicate have the same return type as the class it's defined in. For instance, Strings implementation is 'create_duplicate.String'.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

ctrl_pressed().Boolean
Returns "true" if either of the control keys is currently pressed.

ctrl_pressed( Boolean setting )
Internal use - ctrl_pressed property-set.

dispatch_joystick_button_press( JoystickEvent event )
Sends the given joystick button press event to all registered listeners.

dispatch_joystick_button_release( JoystickEvent event )
Sends the given joystick button release event to all registered listeners.

dispatch_joystick_connected( JoystickEvent event )
Sends the given joystick connected event to all registered listeners.

dispatch_joystick_hat_movement( JoystickEvent event )
Sends the given joystick hat movement event to all registered listeners.

dispatch_joystick_movement( JoystickEvent event )
Sends the given joystick movement event to all registered listeners.

dispatch_key_press( KeyEvent event )
Sends the given key press event to all registered listeners.

dispatch_key_release( KeyEvent event )
Sends the given key release event to all registered listeners.

dispatch_keystroke( KeyEvent event )
Sends the given keystroke event to all registered listeners.

dispatch_mouse_absent()
Sends the given mouse presence event to all registered listeners.

dispatch_mouse_button_press( MouseEvent event )
Sends the given mouse button press event to all registered listeners.

dispatch_mouse_button_release( MouseEvent event )
Sends the given mouse button release event to all registered listeners.

dispatch_mouse_movement( MouseEvent event )
Sends the given mouse movement event to all registered listeners.

dispatch_mouse_position( MouseEvent event )
Sends the given mouse position event to all registered listeners.

dispatch_mouse_present()
Sends the given mouse presence event to all registered listeners.

dispatch_mouse_wheel_down( MouseEvent event )
Sends the given mouse wheel event to all registered listeners.

dispatch_mouse_wheel_up( MouseEvent event )
Sends the given mouse wheel event to all registered listeners.

dispatch_trackball_movement( JoystickEvent event )
Sends the given trackball movement event to all registered listeners.

equals( Object other ).Boolean
Returns true if this object is equivalant to another.

The compiler converts 'obj1 == obj2' into 'obj1.equals(obj2)' and 'obj1 != obj2' into 'not obj1.equals(obj2)'.

Implementations of equals() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

 if (obj1.equals(obj2))
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq
   obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
 else
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
 endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation returns true if the this object and the 'other' reference are the same object ('this is other').

handle_input_event( Int32 type, Real64 param_a, Real64 param_b )
Internal use - called by the native layer to relay input events.

hash_code().Int32
Returns the hash code of this object, which some classes (like HashTable) rely on. This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

Hash codes are used to quickly test and see if two complex objects are NOT equal. The value returned has no intrinsic meaning, but should conform to the following rules:

1. Two objects that are equivalent should produce the same hash code.

2. If an object's state doesn't change, its hash code shouldn't change either. Internally, this precludes the hash code being based on an object's memory address since Slag doesn't guarantee that an object's address won't change over time.

This has the following implications:

If you override hash_code you should also override equals() and possibly compare_to() and ensure the following contract.

Invariant: 

  if (obj1.hash_code != obj2.hash_code)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

init()
joystick_listeners().Readable<<JoystickListener>>
Returns the list of joystick listeners registered with this joystick dispatcher.

key_listeners().Readable<<KeyListener>>
Returns the list of key listeners registered with this key dispatcher.

keycode_to_Char( Int32 keycode ).Char
Converts the given keycode into its Unicode equivalent, taking the current shift keys into consideration.

mouse_listeners().Readable<<MouseListener>>
Returns the list of mouse listeners registered with this mouse dispatcher.

remove_joystick_listener( JoystickListener listener )
Removes the given JoystickListener so that it no longer receives any joystick events from this dispatcher.

remove_key_listener( KeyListener listener )
Removes the given KeyListener so that it no longer receives any key events from this dispatcher.

remove_mouse_listener( MouseListener listener )
Removes the given MouseListener so that it no longer receives any mouse events from this dispatcher.

shift_pressed().Boolean
Returns "true" if either of the shift keys is currently pressed.

shift_pressed( Boolean setting )
Internal use - shift_pressed property-set.

to_String().String
Returns: 
  A String representation of this object.  Most classes
  should override this method to summarize an object's
  state for convenience in testing and debugging.

type_name().String
Returns the true class name of this object. Implemented by the runtime; you should not override this method.

Example: 

  local Object obj = "Hello World"
  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

update()
Internal use - updates the input system.

NoNextValueError

Class NoNextValueError

: Error

Thrown when 'peek' or 'read' is called on a Reader and there is no next value.

Class Methods
create_duplicate( Object existing ).Object
This factory method initiates object duplication. The compiler transforms the duplicate(obj) command into Object.create_duplicate(obj).

Returns: 

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

Object Variables
ip : Int64
The execution ip at the time of the exception. If generated by Slag code this is "manually" calculated (as in 'Global.excecution_ip(-2)') or by the runtime environment if generated by the VM or runtime.

message : String
The error message.

Object Methods
compare_to( Object other ).Ternary
This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

The compiler converts: 

  'obj1 < obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == lt'
  'obj1 > obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == gt'
  'obj1 <= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != gt'
  'obj1 >= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != lt'
Implementations of compare_to() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

  if (obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == true
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  else
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
  endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

create_duplicate().Object
Should create a duplicate of this object such that obj1.equals(obj1.create_duplicate) return true.

The command duplicate(obj) is transformed by the compiler into Object.create_duplicate(obj), which then calls this method.

For optimal performance (by removing an internal typecast in most situations), have your overridden create_duplicate have the same return type as the class it's defined in. For instance, Strings implementation is 'create_duplicate.String'.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

equals( Object other ).Boolean
Returns true if this object is equivalant to another.

The compiler converts 'obj1 == obj2' into 'obj1.equals(obj2)' and 'obj1 != obj2' into 'not obj1.equals(obj2)'.

Implementations of equals() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

 if (obj1.equals(obj2))
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq
   obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
 else
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
 endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation returns true if the this object and the 'other' reference are the same object ('this is other').

hash_code().Int32
Returns the hash code of this object, which some classes (like HashTable) rely on. This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

Hash codes are used to quickly test and see if two complex objects are NOT equal. The value returned has no intrinsic meaning, but should conform to the following rules:

1. Two objects that are equivalent should produce the same hash code.

2. If an object's state doesn't change, its hash code shouldn't change either. Internally, this precludes the hash code being based on an object's memory address since Slag doesn't guarantee that an object's address won't change over time.

This has the following implications:

If you override hash_code you should also override equals() and possibly compare_to() and ensure the following contract.

Invariant: 

  if (obj1.hash_code != obj2.hash_code)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

init( [String message] )
init()
Sets the error message to an empty string.

to_String().String
Returns a description of the execution IP at the time the error was thrown along with the error message.

type_name().String
Returns the true class name of this object. Implemented by the runtime; you should not override this method.

Example: 

  local Object obj = "Hello World"
  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

NoSuchElementError

Class NoSuchElementError

: Error

Thrown by HashTable (at least) when it is queried for the value corresponding to a non-existent key.

Class Methods
create_duplicate( Object existing ).Object
This factory method initiates object duplication. The compiler transforms the duplicate(obj) command into Object.create_duplicate(obj).

Returns: 

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

Object Variables
ip : Int64
The execution ip at the time of the exception. If generated by Slag code this is "manually" calculated (as in 'Global.excecution_ip(-2)') or by the runtime environment if generated by the VM or runtime.

message : String
The error message.

Object Methods
compare_to( Object other ).Ternary
This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

The compiler converts: 

  'obj1 < obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == lt'
  'obj1 > obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == gt'
  'obj1 <= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != gt'
  'obj1 >= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != lt'
Implementations of compare_to() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

  if (obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == true
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  else
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
  endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

create_duplicate().Object
Should create a duplicate of this object such that obj1.equals(obj1.create_duplicate) return true.

The command duplicate(obj) is transformed by the compiler into Object.create_duplicate(obj), which then calls this method.

For optimal performance (by removing an internal typecast in most situations), have your overridden create_duplicate have the same return type as the class it's defined in. For instance, Strings implementation is 'create_duplicate.String'.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

equals( Object other ).Boolean
Returns true if this object is equivalant to another.

The compiler converts 'obj1 == obj2' into 'obj1.equals(obj2)' and 'obj1 != obj2' into 'not obj1.equals(obj2)'.

Implementations of equals() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract:

   obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq
   obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
 else
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
 endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation returns true if the this object and the 'other' reference are the same object ('this is other').

hash_code().Int32
Returns the hash code of this object, which some classes (like HashTable) rely on. This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

Hash codes are used to quickly test and see if two complex objects are NOT equal. The value returned has no intrinsic meaning, but should conform to the following rules:

1. Two objects that are equivalent should produce the same hash code.

2. If an object's state doesn't change, its hash code shouldn't change either. Internally, this precludes the hash code being based on an object's memory address since Slag doesn't guarantee that an object's address won't change over time.

This has the following implications:

If you override hash_code you should also override equals() and possibly compare_to() and ensure the following contract.

Invariant: 

  if (obj1.hash_code != obj2.hash_code)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

init( String element_name )
Creates a custom error message which incorporates the element_name.

init()
Default initializer.

to_String().String
Returns a description of the execution IP at the time the error was thrown along with the error message.

type_name().String
Returns the true class name of this object. Implemented by the runtime; you should not override this method.

Example: 

  local Object obj = "Hello World"
  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

NotPatternMatcher

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

  NullReferenceErrorAccessingArray
