   obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq
   obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
 else
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
 endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation returns true if the this object and the 'other' reference are the same object ('this is other').

hash_code().Int32
Returns the hash code of this object, which some classes (like HashTable) rely on. This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

Hash codes are used to quickly test and see if two complex objects are NOT equal. The value returned has no intrinsic meaning, but should conform to the following rules:

1. Two objects that are equivalent should produce the same hash code.

2. If an object's state doesn't change, its hash code shouldn't change either. Internally, this precludes the hash code being based on an object's memory address since Slag doesn't guarantee that an object's address won't change over time.

This has the following implications:

If you override hash_code you should also override equals() and possibly compare_to() and ensure the following contract.

Invariant: 

  if (obj1.hash_code != obj2.hash_code)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

match( PatternMatchInfo state ).Boolean
match_next( PatternMatchInfo state ).Boolean
matches_any().Boolean
Overridden in CharRangePatternMatcher

to_String().String
Returns: 
  A String representation of this object.  Most classes
  should override this method to summarize an object's
  state for convenience in testing and debugging.

type_name().String
Returns the true class name of this object. Implemented by the runtime; you should not override this method.

Example: 

  local Object obj = "Hello World"
  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

PatternStringReplacementBuilder

Class PatternStringReplacementBuilder

: Reader<<String>>

Internal use - this utility class is used to replace pattern matches in String::replace().

Class Methods
create_duplicate( Object existing ).Object
This factory method initiates object duplication. The compiler transforms the duplicate(obj) command into Object.create_duplicate(obj).

Returns: 

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

Object Variables
counter : Int32
format : String
groups : String[]
has_next : Boolean
next : String

Object Methods
available().Int32
Returns the minimum number of additional values that can be immediately read from this reader.

If the reader is exhausted or if it must block to peek or read next then the result will be 0. It is important to note that '0' does not necessarily mean the reader is exhausted.

Many readers will report that they have 1 available even if there are thousands of values waiting to be read. The 'available' property should be used as an aide for buffer sizes and the like but should not be taken as an absolute size.

build( String[] groups ).String
close()
Closes this reader as a source of input. Useful for file readers, but for most others this command does nothing.

compare_to( Object other ).Ternary
This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

The compiler converts: 

  'obj1 < obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == lt'
  'obj1 > obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == gt'
  'obj1 <= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != gt'
  'obj1 >= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != lt'
Implementations of compare_to() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

  if (obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == true
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  else
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
  endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

consume( DataType look_for ).Boolean
Attempts to match and discard the next value from this reader, returning true, or else leaves the next value still pending and returns false.

Returns: 

  "true" if old.peek == look_for
  "false" if old.peek != look_for
Invariant: 
  if (old.peek == look_for) old.skip

create_duplicate().Object
Should create a duplicate of this object such that obj1.equals(obj1.create_duplicate) return true.

The command duplicate(obj) is transformed by the compiler into Object.create_duplicate(obj), which then calls this method.

For optimal performance (by removing an internal typecast in most situations), have your overridden create_duplicate have the same return type as the class it's defined in. For instance, Strings implementation is 'create_duplicate.String'.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

equals( Object other ).Boolean
Returns true if this object is equivalant to another.

The compiler converts 'obj1 == obj2' into 'obj1.equals(obj2)' and 'obj1 != obj2' into 'not obj1.equals(obj2)'.

Implementations of equals() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

 if (obj1.equals(obj2))
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq
   obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
 else
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
 endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation returns true if the this object and the 'other' reference are the same object ('this is other').

has_another().Boolean
Returns "true" if this reader has another value that can be previewed with peek() or read with read().

hash_code().Int32
Returns the hash code of this object, which some classes (like HashTable) rely on. This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

Hash codes are used to quickly test and see if two complex objects are NOT equal. The value returned has no intrinsic meaning, but should conform to the following rules:

1. Two objects that are equivalent should produce the same hash code.

2. If an object's state doesn't change, its hash code shouldn't change either. Internally, this precludes the hash code being based on an object's memory address since Slag doesn't guarantee that an object's address won't change over time.

This has the following implications:

If you override hash_code you should also override equals() and possibly compare_to() and ensure the following contract.

Invariant: 

  if (obj1.hash_code != obj2.hash_code)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

init( String format )
Initializes this PatternStringReplacementBuilder to read from the given string.

is_exhausted().Boolean
Returns "true" if this reader does not have another value or "false" if it does.

peek().String
Returns the next value that will be returned from read(). If there is no next value then a NoNextValueError is thrown.

position( Int32 new_position )
This optional property-write sets the zero-based read position of this reader. When a reader is first created position() returns 0. After a single read() it returns 1, and so on. Readers that don't implement this property will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

position().Int32
This optional property-read returns the zero-based read position of this reader. When a reader is first created position() returns 0. After a single read() it returns 1, and so on.

Readers that don't implement this property will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

prep_next().Boolean
Prepares the next value that will be used by peek() and read(). Returns "true" if there is another value, "false" if not.

read().String
Returns the next value from this reader. If (not has_another) then a NoNextValueError is thrown.

read_line().String
Reads and returns the next line of characters up to the next LF or CRLF. The CRLF characters are not part of the return value and are discarded.

Only defined for Reader<<Char>>.

read_list( Int32 size ).DataType[]
Reads the next 'size' number of values and returns them in a list. Requires that there are at least 'size' number of values remaining to be read.

remaining().Int32
This optional property returns how many values remain to be read before the reader is exhausted. Not all readers can implement this property; those that don't will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

rewind()
Rewinds this string replacer to the beginning.

skip( [Int32 skip_count] )
Discards exactly the next 'skip_count' number of values rather than reading them. If there are not enough values remaining then a NoNextValueError will be thrown from read().

This program fragment: 

  local var a = reader.read
  reader.read
  reader.read
  local var b = reader.read
is equivalent to this: 
  local var a = reader.read
  reader.skip(2)
  local var b = reader.read

to_List().DataType[]
Creates and returns a list of all the remaining values of this reader.

to_String().String
Returns a string representation of this reader's values.

type_name().String
Returns the true class name of this object. Implemented by the runtime; you should not override this method.

Example: 

  local Object obj = "Hello World"
  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

PrintWriter

Class PrintWriter

: Writer<<Char>>

Defines a Writer<<Char>> that can print a variety of common Slag types in text form.

In Slag I/O terminology, "writing" data means to write successive units of that data type to the output, while "printing" means to translate into text form.

Class Methods
create_duplicate( Object existing ).Object
This factory method initiates object duplication. The compiler transforms the duplicate(obj) command into Object.create_duplicate(obj).

Returns: 

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

Object Methods
capacity().Int32
Returns the minimum number of additional values that can written with this writer, or (-1) for "unlimited".

clean_up()
Closes the writer. Base aspect Writer does not incorporate the RequiresCleanup interface, but types for writers that do this method will be called when there are no more references to the object.

close()
Closes the writer; no further information may be written to this writer. Should always be called after data is finished being written.

Implementations should call flush() as the first step of close().

Multiple calls to a writer's close() are permitted although only the first call actually causes an action.

compare_to( Object other ).Ternary
This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

The compiler converts: 

  'obj1 < obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == lt'
  'obj1 > obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == gt'
  'obj1 <= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != gt'
  'obj1 >= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != lt'
Implementations of compare_to() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

  if (obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == true
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  else
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
  endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

create_duplicate().Object
Should create a duplicate of this object such that obj1.equals(obj1.create_duplicate) return true.

The command duplicate(obj) is transformed by the compiler into Object.create_duplicate(obj), which then calls this method.

For optimal performance (by removing an internal typecast in most situations), have your overridden create_duplicate have the same return type as the class it's defined in. For instance, Strings implementation is 'create_duplicate.String'.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

equals( Object other ).Boolean
Returns true if this object is equivalant to another.

The compiler converts 'obj1 == obj2' into 'obj1.equals(obj2)' and 'obj1 != obj2' into 'not obj1.equals(obj2)'.

Implementations of equals() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

 if (obj1.equals(obj2))
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq
   obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
 else
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
 endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation returns true if the this object and the 'other' reference are the same object ('this is other').

flush()
Orders the writer to write out any buffered data in preparations for closing the writer.

Invariant: 

  close() should always call flush() first.

hash_code().Int32
Returns the hash code of this object, which some classes (like HashTable) rely on. This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

Hash codes are used to quickly test and see if two complex objects are NOT equal. The value returned has no intrinsic meaning, but should conform to the following rules:

1. Two objects that are equivalent should produce the same hash code.

2. If an object's state doesn't change, its hash code shouldn't change either. Internally, this precludes the hash code being based on an object's memory address since Slag doesn't guarantee that an object's address won't change over time.

This has the following implications:

If you override hash_code you should also override equals() and possibly compare_to() and ensure the following contract.

Invariant: 

  if (obj1.hash_code != obj2.hash_code)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

holds_has_another().Boolean
Returns true if at least one more value can be written with write().

position().Int32
This optional property-read returns the zero-based write position. This will be "0" before anything is written, "1" after a single write(), and so on.

Not all writers implement this property; those that don't will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

position( Int32 new_pos )
This optional property-write sets the zero-based write position. It is up to the implementation to define how repositioning works with gaps and what happens to data at a later spot after a reposition to an earlier spot.

Not all writers implement this property; those that don't will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

print( Char ch )
Prints the given Char. The symbol corresponding to the Unicode value of 'n' will be displayed.

print( Byte n )
Prints the given Byte in text form.

print( Degrees deg )
Prints out the given degrees value.

print( Boolean n )
Prints the given Boolean in text form as "true" or "false".

print( Reader<<Char>> reader )
Prints out every character that can be obtained from the reader.

print( Real32 n )
Prints the given Real32 in text form.

print( Line line )
Prints 'line' in text form.

print( Real64 n )
Prints the given Real64 in text form.

print( HSV hsv )
Prints 'hsv' in text form.

print( Readable<<Char>> readable )
Prints out every character in the Readable data.

print( Int64 n )
Prints the given Int64 in text form.

print( Object obj )
Prints the to_String representation of the given object, or else the world "null" if the 'obj' reference is null.

print( String st )
Prints the given String.

print( Color c )
Prints 'c' in text form.

print( Circle circle )
Prints 'circle in text form.

print( Ternary n )
Prints the given Ternary in text form as "yes", "no", or "void".

print( Radians rad )
Prints out the given radians value.

print( RealColor argb )
Prints 'argb' in text form.

print( Quad q )
Prints 'q' in text form.

print( Vector2 v )
Prints 'v' in text form.

print( Corners c )
Prints 'v' in text form.

print( Rect r )
Prints 'r' in text form.

print( ParsePos p )
Prints the given ParsePos in text form.

println( Line line )
Prints 'line' in text form and advances the cursor to the next line of text output.

println( Quad q )
Prints 'q' in text form and advances the cursor to the next line.

println( Rect r )
Prints 'r' in text form and advances the cursor to the next line.

println( Radians rad )
Prints out the given radians value and advances the cursor to the next line.

println( Ternary n )
Prints the given Ternary value and advances the cursor to the next line.

println( Int64 n )
Prints the given Int64 value and advances the cursor to the next line.

println( Real64 n )
Prints the given Real64 value and advances the cursor to the next line.

println( String st )
Prints the given String value and advances the cursor to the next line.

println( Color c )
Prints 'c' in text form and advances the cursor to the next line.

println( Degrees deg )
Prints out the given degrees value and advances the cursor to the next line.

println( Boolean n )
Prints the given Boolean value and advances the cursor to the next line.

println( Byte n )
Prints the given Byte value and advances the cursor to the next line.

println( Corners c )
Prints 'v' in text form and advances the cursor to the next line.

println( Vector2 v )
Prints 'v' in text form and advances the cursor to the next line.

println()
Advances the cursor to the next line.

println( ParsePos p )
Prints the given ParsePos in text form and advances the cursor to the next line.

println( Circle circle )
Prints 'circle' in text form and advances the cursor to the next circle of text output.

println( Readable<<Char>> readable )
Prints out every character in the Readable data and advances the cursor to the next line.

println( Char n )
Prints the given Char value and advances the cursor to the next line.

println( Object obj )
Prints the given object's to_String value and advances the cursor to the next line.

println( RealColor argb )
Prints 'argb' in text form and advances the cursor to the next line.

println( HSV hsv )
Prints 'hsv' in text form and advances the cursor to the next line.

println( Reader<<Char>> reader )
Prints out every character that can be obtained from the reader and advances the cursor to the next line.

skip( Int32 skip_count )
This optional method repositions the writer to be 'skip_count' values further along.

If a writer does not implement the 'position' property then an UnsupportedMethodError will be generated when skip() is called.

to_String().String
Returns: 
  A String representation of this object.  Most classes
  should override this method to summarize an object's
  state for convenience in testing and debugging.

type_name().String
Returns the true class name of this object. Implemented by the runtime; you should not override this method.

Example: 

  local Object obj = "Hello World"
  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

write( DataType value )
Outputs 'value' in an implementation-specific way.

Requires: 

  holds_has_another == true

Process

Class Process

: RequiresCleanup

Wrapper for an index-based native process. You should not create Process objects directly but instead obtain them from System.execute().

Class Methods
create_duplicate( Object existing ).Object
This factory method initiates object duplication. The compiler transforms the duplicate(obj) command into Object.create_duplicate(obj).

Returns: 

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

Object Variables
process_id : Int32

Object Methods
clean_up()
Internal use. Calls release().

compare_to( Object other ).Ternary
This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

The compiler converts: 

  'obj1 < obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == lt'
  'obj1 > obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == gt'
  'obj1 <= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != gt'
  'obj1 >= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != lt'
Implementations of compare_to() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

  if (obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == true
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  else
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
  endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

create_duplicate().Object
Should create a duplicate of this object such that obj1.equals(obj1.create_duplicate) return true.

The command duplicate(obj) is transformed by the compiler into Object.create_duplicate(obj), which then calls this method.

For optimal performance (by removing an internal typecast in most situations), have your overridden create_duplicate have the same return type as the class it's defined in. For instance, Strings implementation is 'create_duplicate.String'.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

equals( Object other ).Boolean
Returns true if this object is equivalant to another.

The compiler converts 'obj1 == obj2' into 'obj1.equals(obj2)' and 'obj1 != obj2' into 'not obj1.equals(obj2)'.

Implementations of equals() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

 if (obj1.equals(obj2))
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq
   obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
 else
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
 endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation returns true if the this object and the 'other' reference are the same object ('this is other').

exit_code().Int32
Returns the exit code from this process.

Throws an Error if this process is not yet finished.

hash_code().Int32
Returns the hash code of this object, which some classes (like HashTable) rely on. This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

Hash codes are used to quickly test and see if two complex objects are NOT equal. The value returned has no intrinsic meaning, but should conform to the following rules:

1. Two objects that are equivalent should produce the same hash code.

2. If an object's state doesn't change, its hash code shouldn't change either. Internally, this precludes the hash code being based on an object's memory address since Slag doesn't guarantee that an object's address won't change over time.

This has the following implications:

If you override hash_code you should also override equals() and possibly compare_to() and ensure the following contract.

Invariant: 

  if (obj1.hash_code != obj2.hash_code)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

init( Int32 process_id )
Internal use.

Default initializer.

is_active().Boolean
Returns "true" if this process is still active and has not exited.

release()
Releases any resources associated with this process.

to_String().String
Returns: 
  A String representation of this object.  Most classes
  should override this method to summarize an object's
  state for convenience in testing and debugging.

type_name().String
Returns the true class name of this object. Implemented by the runtime; you should not override this method.

Example: 

  local Object obj = "Hello World"
  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

wait_for_exit( [Int32 sleep_ms] ).Int32
Waits for this process to exit and then returns the exit code. 'sleep_ms' specifys the number of milliseconds to wait inbetween checks for process completion [default: 50ms].

Pump<<DataType>>

Class Pump<<DataType>>

A pump ties a reader together with one or more writers and pipes through some or all of the input data as desired.

For example, to dump the contents of a given file to the standard output: 

  Pump<<Char>>( File("test.slag"), stdout ).pump_all

Class Methods
create_duplicate( Object existing ).Object
This factory method initiates object duplication. The compiler transforms the duplicate(obj) command into Object.create_duplicate(obj).

Returns: 

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

Object Variables
input : Reader<<DataType>>
The source of input for the pump.

outputs : Writer<<DataType>>[]
The list of outputs for the pump.

Object Methods
compare_to( Object other ).Ternary
This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

The compiler converts: 

  'obj1 < obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == lt'
  'obj1 > obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == gt'
  'obj1 <= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != gt'
  'obj1 >= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != lt'
Implementations of compare_to() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

  if (obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == true
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  else
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
  endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

create_duplicate().Object
Should create a duplicate of this object such that obj1.equals(obj1.create_duplicate) return true.

The command duplicate(obj) is transformed by the compiler into Object.create_duplicate(obj), which then calls this method.

For optimal performance (by removing an internal typecast in most situations), have your overridden create_duplicate have the same return type as the class it's defined in. For instance, Strings implementation is 'create_duplicate.String'.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

equals( Object other ).Boolean
Returns true if this object is equivalant to another.

The compiler converts 'obj1 == obj2' into 'obj1.equals(obj2)' and 'obj1 != obj2' into 'not obj1.equals(obj2)'.

Implementations of equals() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

 if (obj1.equals(obj2))
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq
   obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
 else
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
 endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation returns true if the this object and the 'other' reference are the same object ('this is other').

has_another().Boolean
Returns "true" if this reader has another value that can be previewed with peek() or read with read().

hash_code().Int32
Returns the hash code of this object, which some classes (like HashTable) rely on. This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

Hash codes are used to quickly test and see if two complex objects are NOT equal. The value returned has no intrinsic meaning, but should conform to the following rules:

1. Two objects that are equivalent should produce the same hash code.

2. If an object's state doesn't change, its hash code shouldn't change either. Internally, this precludes the hash code being based on an object's memory address since Slag doesn't guarantee that an object's address won't change over time.

This has the following implications:

If you override hash_code you should also override equals() and possibly compare_to() and ensure the following contract.

Invariant: 

  if (obj1.hash_code != obj2.hash_code)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

init( Readable<<DataType>> readable, Writer<<DataType>> output )
init( Reader<<DataType>> input, [Writer<<DataType>> output] )
init( Reader<<DataType>> input, Writable<<DataType>> output )
init( Readable<<DataType>> readable, [Writable<<DataType>> output] )
pump( Int32 max_count ).Int32
Pumps up to 'max_count' values. Returns the number of values actually pumped; if less than 'max_count' then the backing input was exhaused part-way though.

pump_all().Int32
Pumps all remaining values until the input is exhausted. Returns the number of values pumped.

pump_next().Boolean
Attempts to pump a single value from input to outputs; returns "true" if successful or "false" if the the input is exhausted.

to_String().String
Returns: 
  A String representation of this object.  Most classes
  should override this method to summarize an object's
  state for convenience in testing and debugging.

type_name().String
Returns the true class name of this object. Implemented by the runtime; you should not override this method.

Example: 

  local Object obj = "Hello World"
  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

Quad

Compound Quad ( Vector2 top_left, Vector2 top_right, Vector2 bottom_right, Vector2 bottom_left )

Defines an abstract geometric quadrangle composed of four vertices.

Quad-related methods in class Global
  print( Quad q )
  println( Quad q )
  to_String( Quad q ).String

Composite Elements
top_left : Vector2
top_right : Vector2
bottom_right : Vector2
bottom_left : Vector2

RENDER

Class RENDER

RENDER constants that can be passed to many of the drawing methods and stored with Images as "render_flags".

Class Variables
fixed_color : Int32
Specifies that an image should be drawn with its normal alpha but using a constant color (specified by the image's 'color' property). Good for silhouette effects.

Images have 'fixed_color' convenience methods that access this flag.

overexpose : Int32
Specifies that an image should be drawn in "overexpose" mode, where color values are added to the destination rather than being blended with it.

Images have 'overexpose' convenience methods that access this flag.

point_filter : Int32
Specifies that an image should be drawn using point filtering (no smoothing). An image without the point_filter flag will be drawn with linear filtering (smoothing).

Images have 'point_filter' and 'linear_filter' convenience methods that access this flag.

texture_wrap : Int32
When an image's UV texture coordinates are adjusted to be larger than actual texture, this flag causes the texture to wrap. For example, setting the UV coordinates to (0,0), (3,2) would cause an image to tile 3 times horizontally and 2 times vertically within its normal image area when it's drawn. The absence of texture_wrap indicates texture clamp (the image default).

Images have 'texture_wrap' convenience methods that access this flag.

Class Methods
create_duplicate( Object existing ).Object
This factory method initiates object duplication. The compiler transforms the duplicate(obj) command into Object.create_duplicate(obj).

Returns: 

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

Object Methods

This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

Radians

Compound Radians ( Real64 value )

Real64 wrapper compound that specifies an angle in radians.

Radians compounds may be used in trig operations such as sin() and cos().

  asin( Real64 yp ).Radians
  atan( Real64 slope ).Radians

  new_Vector2( Real64 magnitude, Radians angle ).Vector2
  op*( Real64 factor, Radians rad ).Radians
  op+( Degrees deg, Radians rad ).Degrees
  op-( Radians rad1 ).Radians
  op-( Degrees deg, Radians rad ).Degrees
  op/( Real64 factor, Radians rad ).Radians
  point_at( Circle circle, Radians angle ).Vector2
  print( Radians rad )

  radians_of( Vector2 v ).Radians
  random_Radians().Radians
  rotate( Vector2 v, Radians rad ).Vector2

  tan( Radians rad ).Real64
  to_Degrees( Radians rad ).Degrees
  to_String( Radians rad ).String

Composite Elements
value : Real64

RandomGeneratorBase

Class RandomGeneratorBase

: Generator<<Int64>>

This random number generator produces pseudo-random, evenly-distributed 48-bit integers using the linear congruence formula with the "drand48" parameters: 

  next = (a * prev + c) mod (2^48)
Where a=0x5DEECE66D, c=11, and the upper 32 bits of 'next' are retrieved with each call to read().

Class Methods
create_duplicate( Object existing ).Object
This factory method initiates object duplication. The compiler transforms the duplicate(obj) command into Object.create_duplicate(obj).

Returns: 

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

Object Variables
a : Int64
A linear congruence constant.

c : Int64
A linear congruence constant.

next : Int64
The next value that will be returned by read() or peek().

Object Methods
available().Int32
Returns the minimum number of additional values that can be immediately read from this reader.

If the reader is exhausted or if it must block to peek or read next then the result will be 0. It is important to note that '0' does not necessarily mean the reader is exhausted.

Many readers will report that they have 1 available even if there are thousands of values waiting to be read. The 'available' property should be used as an aide for buffer sizes and the like but should not be taken as an absolute size.

close()
Closes this reader as a source of input. Useful for file readers, but for most others this command does nothing.

compare_to( Object other ).Ternary
This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

The compiler converts: 

  'obj1 < obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == lt'
  'obj1 > obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == gt'
  'obj1 <= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != gt'
  'obj1 >= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != lt'
Implementations of compare_to() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

  if (obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == true
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  else
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
  endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

consume( DataType look_for ).Boolean
Attempts to match and discard the next value from this reader, returning true, or else leaves the next value still pending and returns false.

Returns: 

  "true" if old.peek == look_for
  "false" if old.peek != look_for
Invariant: 
  if (old.peek == look_for) old.skip

create_duplicate().RandomGeneratorBase
Handles duplicating this iterator when "duplicate(iterator_obj)" is called.

equals( Object other ).Boolean
Returns true if this object is equivalant to another.

The compiler converts 'obj1 == obj2' into 'obj1.equals(obj2)' and 'obj1 != obj2' into 'not obj1.equals(obj2)'.

Implementations of equals() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

 if (obj1.equals(obj2))
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq
   obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
 else
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
 endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation returns true if the this object and the 'other' reference are the same object ('this is other').

has_another().Boolean
Returns true - standard generators always have another value.

hash_code().Int32
Returns the hash code of this object, which some classes (like HashTable) rely on. This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

Hash codes are used to quickly test and see if two complex objects are NOT equal. The value returned has no intrinsic meaning, but should conform to the following rules:

1. Two objects that are equivalent should produce the same hash code.

2. If an object's state doesn't change, its hash code shouldn't change either. Internally, this precludes the hash code being based on an object's memory address since Slag doesn't guarantee that an object's address won't change over time.

This has the following implications:

If you override hash_code you should also override equals() and possibly compare_to() and ensure the following contract.

Invariant: 

  if (obj1.hash_code != obj2.hash_code)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

init( [Int64 seed_value] )
Initializes this random number generator with the given seed_value (default: the current time in milliseconds). Different seed values produce different sequences of pseudo-random numbers.

is_exhausted().Boolean
Returns "true" if this reader does not have another value or "false" if it does.

peek().Int64
Returns the integer that will be the result of the next read().

position( Int32 new_position )
This optional property-write sets the zero-based read position of this reader. When a reader is first created position() returns 0. After a single read() it returns 1, and so on. Readers that don't implement this property will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

position().Int32
This optional property-read returns the zero-based read position of this reader. When a reader is first created position() returns 0. After a single read() it returns 1, and so on.

Readers that don't implement this property will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

read().Int64
Returns the next integer in the current pseudo-random sequence.

read_line().String
Reads and returns the next line of characters up to the next LF or CRLF. The CRLF characters are not part of the return value and are discarded.

Only defined for Reader<<Char>>.

read_list( Int32 size ).DataType[]
Reads the next 'size' number of values and returns them in a list. Requires that there are at least 'size' number of values remaining to be read.

remaining().Int32
This optional property returns how many values remain to be read before the reader is exhausted. Not all readers can implement this property; those that don't will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

rewind()
This optional method resets this reader so that the next read() will return the first value of the series. Readers that don't implement this property will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

skip( Int32 skip_count )
Discards 'skip_count' number of values that would otherwise be returned from this generator.

to_List().DataType[]
Throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

to_String().String
Returns a string representation of this reader's values.

type_name().String
Returns the true class name of this object. Implemented by the runtime; you should not override this method.

Example: 

  local Object obj = "Hello World"
  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

RandomInt32Generator

Class RandomInt32Generator

: Generator<<Int32>>

Returns integers in a desired range (0..0x7fffffff by default).

Class Methods

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

Object Variables
next : Int32
The next integer to be returned by read() or peek().

scale : Int64
Transformation factor to adjust the output values from (0.0,1.0) to a user-specified range.

src : RandomReal64Generator
Source of normalized real numbers - the easiest way to convert to an arbitrary integer range.

translate : Int64
Transformation factor to adjust the output values from (0.0,1.0) to a user-specified range.

  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

init( Int32 lower_limit, Int32 upper_limit )
Initializes the random number generator with arbitrary limits. For example, RandomReal64Generator(1,5) would return numbers in the range [1,5] inclusive.

init( RandomReal64Generator src, Int32 next, Int64 scale, Int64 translate )
init( [Int64 seed_value], [Int32 lower_limit], [Int32 upper_limit] )
Initializes the random number generator with an arbitrary seed value (default: current time in ms) and arbitrary range limits (default: 0 to 0x7fffffff inclusive).

is_exhausted().Boolean
Returns "true" if this reader does not have another value or "false" if it does.

peek().Int32
Returns the next random number that will be returned from read().

position( Int32 new_position )
This optional property-write sets the zero-based read position of this reader. When a reader is first created position() returns 0. After a single read() it returns 1, and so on. Readers that don't implement this property will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

position().Int32
This optional property-read returns the zero-based read position of this reader. When a reader is first created position() returns 0. After a single read() it returns 1, and so on.

Readers that don't implement this property will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

prep_next()
Internal use: calculates the 'next' random number.

read().Int32
Returns the next pseudo-random number from this sequence.

read_line().String
Reads and returns the next line of characters up to the next LF or CRLF. The CRLF characters are not part of the return value and are discarded.

Only defined for Reader<<Char>>.

This optional property returns how many values remain to be read before the reader is exhausted. Not all readers can implement this property; those that don't will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

This optional method resets this reader so that the next read() will return the first value of the series. Readers that don't implement this property will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

Discards 'skip_count' number of values that would otherwise be returned from this generator.

Example: 

  local Object obj = "Hello World"
  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

RandomReal64Generator

Class RandomReal64Generator

: Generator<<Real64>>

This random number generator returns real numbers in the default range of (0.0,1.0) exclusive. The upper and lower limits of the range can also be set as desired.

Class Methods
create_duplicate( Object existing ).Object
This factory method initiates object duplication. The compiler transforms the duplicate(obj) command into Object.create_duplicate(obj).

Returns: 

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

Object Variables
next : Real64
The next real number to be returned by read() or peek().

scale : Real64
Transformation factor to adjust the output values from (0.0,1.0) to a user-specified range.

src : RandomGeneratorBase
The source of 48-bit pseudo-random integers this generator uses in its calculations.

translate : Real64
Transformation factor to adjust the output values from (0.0,1.0) to a user-specified range.

Object Methods
available().Int32
Returns the minimum number of additional values that can be immediately read from this reader.

If the reader is exhausted or if it must block to peek or read next then the result will be 0. It is important to note that '0' does not necessarily mean the reader is exhausted.

Many readers will report that they have 1 available even if there are thousands of values waiting to be read. The 'available' property should be used as an aide for buffer sizes and the like but should not be taken as an absolute size.

close()
Closes this reader as a source of input. Useful for file readers, but for most others this command does nothing.

compare_to( Object other ).Ternary
This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

The compiler converts: 

  'obj1 < obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == lt'
  'obj1 > obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == gt'
  'obj1 <= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != gt'
  'obj1 >= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != lt'
Implementations of compare_to() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

  if (obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == true
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  else
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
  endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

consume( DataType look_for ).Boolean
Attempts to match and discard the next value from this reader, returning true, or else leaves the next value still pending and returns false.

Returns: 

  "true" if old.peek == look_for
  "false" if old.peek != look_for
Invariant: 
  if (old.peek == look_for) old.skip

create_duplicate().RandomReal64Generator
Handles duplicating this iterator when "duplicate(iterator_obj)" is called.

equals( Object other ).Boolean
Returns true if this object is equivalant to another.

The compiler converts 'obj1 == obj2' into 'obj1.equals(obj2)' and 'obj1 != obj2' into 'not obj1.equals(obj2)'.

Implementations of equals() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

 if (obj1.equals(obj2))
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq
   obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
 else
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
 endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation returns true if the this object and the 'other' reference are the same object ('this is other').

has_another().Boolean
Returns true - standard generators always have another value.

hash_code().Int32
Returns the hash code of this object, which some classes (like HashTable) rely on. This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

Hash codes are used to quickly test and see if two complex objects are NOT equal. The value returned has no intrinsic meaning, but should conform to the following rules:

1. Two objects that are equivalent should produce the same hash code.

2. If an object's state doesn't change, its hash code shouldn't change either. Internally, this precludes the hash code being based on an object's memory address since Slag doesn't guarantee that an object's address won't change over time.

This has the following implications:

If you override hash_code you should also override equals() and possibly compare_to() and ensure the following contract.

Invariant: 

  if (obj1.hash_code != obj2.hash_code)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

init( RandomGeneratorBase src, Real64 next, Real64 scale, Real64 translate )
init( Real64 lower_limit, Real64 upper_limit )
Initializes the random number generator with arbitrary limits. For example, RandomReal64Generator(0.25,0.75) would return numbers in the range (0.25,0.75) exclusive (would never result in exactly 0.25 or 0.75).

init( [Int64 seed_value], [Real64 lower_limit], [Real64 upper_limit] )
Initializes the random number generator with an arbitrary seed value (default: current time in ms) and arbitrary range limits (default: 0.0 to 1.0 exclusive).

is_exhausted().Boolean
Returns "true" if this reader does not have another value or "false" if it does.

peek().Real64
Returns the next random number that will be returned from read().

position( Int32 new_position )
This optional property-write sets the zero-based read position of this reader. When a reader is first created position() returns 0. After a single read() it returns 1, and so on. Readers that don't implement this property will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

position().Int32
This optional property-read returns the zero-based read position of this reader. When a reader is first created position() returns 0. After a single read() it returns 1, and so on.

Readers that don't implement this property will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

prep_next()
Internal use: calculates the 'next' random number.

read().Real64
Returns the next pseudo-random number from this sequence.

read_line().String
Reads and returns the next line of characters up to the next LF or CRLF. The CRLF characters are not part of the return value and are discarded.

Only defined for Reader<<Char>>.

read_list( Int32 size ).DataType[]
Reads the next 'size' number of values and returns them in a list. Requires that there are at least 'size' number of values remaining to be read.

remaining().Int32
This optional property returns how many values remain to be read before the reader is exhausted. Not all readers can implement this property; those that don't will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

rewind()
This optional method resets this reader so that the next read() will return the first value of the series. Readers that don't implement this property will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

skip( Int32 skip_count )
Discards 'skip_count' number of values that would otherwise be returned from this generator.

to_List().DataType[]
Throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

to_String().String
Returns a string representation of this reader's values.

type_name().String
Returns the true class name of this object. Implemented by the runtime; you should not override this method.

Example: 

  local Object obj = "Hello World"
  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

Range<<DataType>>

Class Range<<DataType>>

: Readable<<DataType>>, RangeType, ListAdaptable<<DataType>>

Models a range of numbers with a first value, a last value, and a step size. This base range class spans the ascending or descending range [first,last] in steps of 'step_size'.

Range objects are normally created by the compiler from "low..high" or "low upTo high" expressions.

Class Methods
create_duplicate( Object existing ).Object
This factory method initiates object duplication. The compiler transforms the duplicate(obj) command into Object.create_duplicate(obj).

Returns: 

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

Object Variables
first : DataType
last : DataType
step_size : DataType

Object Methods
compare_to( Object other ).Ternary
This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

The compiler converts: 

  'obj1 < obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == lt'
  'obj1 > obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == gt'
  'obj1 <= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != gt'
  'obj1 >= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != lt'
Implementations of compare_to() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

  if (obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == true
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  else
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
  endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

create_duplicate().Object
Should create a duplicate of this object such that obj1.equals(obj1.create_duplicate) return true.

The command duplicate(obj) is transformed by the compiler into Object.create_duplicate(obj), which then calls this method.

For optimal performance (by removing an internal typecast in most situations), have your overridden create_duplicate have the same return type as the class it's defined in. For instance, Strings implementation is 'create_duplicate.String'.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

create_reader().Reader<<DataType>>
equals( Object other ).Boolean
Returns true if this object is equivalant to another.

The compiler converts 'obj1 == obj2' into 'obj1.equals(obj2)' and 'obj1 != obj2' into 'not obj1.equals(obj2)'.

Implementations of equals() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

 if (obj1.equals(obj2))
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq
   obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
 else
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
 endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation returns true if the this object and the 'other' reference are the same object ('this is other').

hash_code().Int32
Returns the hash code of this object, which some classes (like HashTable) rely on. This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

Hash codes are used to quickly test and see if two complex objects are NOT equal. The value returned has no intrinsic meaning, but should conform to the following rules:

1. Two objects that are equivalent should produce the same hash code.

2. If an object's state doesn't change, its hash code shouldn't change either. Internally, this precludes the hash code being based on an object's memory address since Slag doesn't guarantee that an object's address won't change over time.

This has the following implications:

If you override hash_code you should also override equals() and possibly compare_to() and ensure the following contract.

Invariant: 

  if (obj1.hash_code != obj2.hash_code)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

init( DataType first, DataType last )
init( DataType first, DataType last, DataType step_size )
is_contiguous_ascending().Boolean
For enumerated types:

Returns false.

to_List().ArrayList<<DataType>>
Creates and returns a list containing all the values in this range.

to_String().String
Returns a string representation of all the values in this range.

type_name().String
Returns the true class name of this object. Implemented by the runtime; you should not override this method.

Example: 

  local Object obj = "Hello World"
  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

RangeGE<<DataType>>

Class RangeGE<<DataType>>

: Range<<DataType>>

Specialized descending range that spans [first,last] in steps of 'step_size'.

RangeGE objects are normally created by the compiler from "high downTo low" expressions.

Class Methods

  'null' if 'existing' is null.

This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

The compiler converts: 

  'obj1 < obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == lt'
  'obj1 > obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == gt'

create_reader().Reader<<DataType>>
Returns a reader that will step through each value in this range.

equals( Object other ).Boolean
Returns true if this object is equivalant to another.

The compiler converts 'obj1 == obj2' into 'obj1.equals(obj2)' and 'obj1 != obj2' into 'not obj1.equals(obj2)'.

Implementations of equals() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

   obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq
   obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
 else
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
 endIf

This default implementation returns true if the this object and the 'other' reference are the same object ('this is other').

hash_code().Int32
Returns the hash code of this object, which some classes (like HashTable) rely on. This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

Hash codes are used to quickly test and see if two complex objects are NOT equal. The value returned has no intrinsic meaning, but should conform to the following rules:

1. Two objects that are equivalent should produce the same hash code.

2. If an object's state doesn't change, its hash code shouldn't change either. Internally, this precludes the hash code being based on an object's memory address since Slag doesn't guarantee that an object's address won't change over time.

This has the following implications:

If you override hash_code you should also override equals() and possibly compare_to() and ensure the following contract.

Invariant:

    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

RangeGT<<DataType>>

Class RangeGT<<DataType>>

: Range<<DataType>>

Specialized descending range that spans [first,last) in steps of 'step_size'.

RangeGT objects are normally created by the compiler from "high..>low" or "high downToGreaterThan low" expressions.

create_reader().Reader<<DataType>>
Returns a reader that will step through each value in this range.

RangeIteratorAscending<<DataType>>

Class RangeIteratorAscending<<DataType>>

: Reader<<DataType>>

A reader that steps through an ascending range of numbers and includes the last value.

Created by Range objects.

Class Methods
create_duplicate( Object existing ).Object
This factory method initiates object duplication. The compiler transforms the duplicate(obj) command into Object.create_duplicate(obj).

Returns: 

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

Object Variables
last_value : DataType
next_value : DataType
step_size : DataType

Object Methods
available().Int32
Returns the minimum number of additional values that can be immediately read from this reader.

If the reader is exhausted or if it must block to peek or read next then the result will be 0. It is important to note that '0' does not necessarily mean the reader is exhausted.

Many readers will report that they have 1 available even if there are thousands of values waiting to be read. The 'available' property should be used as an aide for buffer sizes and the like but should not be taken as an absolute size.

close()
Closes this reader as a source of input. Useful for file readers, but for most others this command does nothing.

compare_to( Object other ).Ternary
This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

The compiler converts: 

  'obj1 < obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == lt'
  'obj1 > obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == gt'
  'obj1 <= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != gt'
  'obj1 >= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != lt'
Implementations of compare_to() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

  if (obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == true
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  else
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
  endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

consume( DataType look_for ).Boolean
Attempts to match and discard the next value from this reader, returning true, or else leaves the next value still pending and returns false.

Returns: 

  "true" if old.peek == look_for
  "false" if old.peek != look_for
Invariant: 
  if (old.peek == look_for) old.skip

create_duplicate().RangeIteratorAscending<<DataType>>
Handles duplicating this iterator when "duplicate(iterator_obj)" is called.

equals( Object other ).Boolean
Returns true if this object is equivalant to another.

The compiler converts 'obj1 == obj2' into 'obj1.equals(obj2)' and 'obj1 != obj2' into 'not obj1.equals(obj2)'.

Implementations of equals() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

 if (obj1.equals(obj2))
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq
   obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
 else
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
 endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation returns true if the this object and the 'other' reference are the same object ('this is other').

has_another().Boolean
Returns "true" if this reader has another value that can be previewed with peek() or read with read().

hash_code().Int32
Returns the hash code of this object, which some classes (like HashTable) rely on. This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

Hash codes are used to quickly test and see if two complex objects are NOT equal. The value returned has no intrinsic meaning, but should conform to the following rules:

1. Two objects that are equivalent should produce the same hash code.

2. If an object's state doesn't change, its hash code shouldn't change either. Internally, this precludes the hash code being based on an object's memory address since Slag doesn't guarantee that an object's address won't change over time.

This has the following implications:

If you override hash_code you should also override equals() and possibly compare_to() and ensure the following contract.

Invariant: 

  if (obj1.hash_code != obj2.hash_code)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

init( DataType first_value, DataType last_value, DataType step_size )
is_exhausted().Boolean
Returns "true" if this reader does not have another value or "false" if it does.

peek().DataType
Returns the next value that will be returned from read(). If there is no next value then a NoNextValueError is thrown.

position( Int32 new_position )
This optional property-write sets the zero-based read position of this reader. When a reader is first created position() returns 0. After a single read() it returns 1, and so on. Readers that don't implement this property will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

position().Int32
This optional property-read returns the zero-based read position of this reader. When a reader is first created position() returns 0. After a single read() it returns 1, and so on.

Readers that don't implement this property will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

read().DataType
Returns the next value from this reader. If (not has_another) then a NoNextValueError is thrown.

read_line().String
Reads and returns the next line of characters up to the next LF or CRLF. The CRLF characters are not part of the return value and are discarded.

Only defined for Reader<<Char>>.

read_list( Int32 size ).DataType[]
Reads the next 'size' number of values and returns them in a list. Requires that there are at least 'size' number of values remaining to be read.

remaining().Int32
This optional property returns how many values remain to be read before the reader is exhausted. Not all readers can implement this property; those that don't will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

rewind()
This optional method resets this reader so that the next read() will return the first value of the series. Readers that don't implement this property will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

skip( [Int32 skip_count] )
Discards exactly the next 'skip_count' number of values rather than reading them. If there are not enough values remaining then a NoNextValueError will be thrown from read().

This program fragment: 

  local var a = reader.read
  reader.read
  reader.read
  local var b = reader.read
is equivalent to this: 
  local var a = reader.read
  reader.skip(2)
  local var b = reader.read

to_List().DataType[]
Creates and returns a list of all the remaining values of this reader.

to_String().String
Returns a string representation of this reader's values.

type_name().String
Returns the true class name of this object. Implemented by the runtime; you should not override this method.

Example: 

  local Object obj = "Hello World"
  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

RangeIteratorDescending<<DataType>>

Class RangeIteratorDescending<<DataType>>

: Reader<<DataType>>

A reader that steps through a descending range of numbers and includes the last value.

Created by Range objects.

Class Methods
create_duplicate( Object existing ).Object
This factory method initiates object duplication. The compiler transforms the duplicate(obj) command into Object.create_duplicate(obj).

Returns: 

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

Object Variables
last_value : DataType
next_value : DataType
step_size : DataType

Object Methods
available().Int32
Returns the minimum number of additional values that can be immediately read from this reader.

If the reader is exhausted or if it must block to peek or read next then the result will be 0. It is important to note that '0' does not necessarily mean the reader is exhausted.

Many readers will report that they have 1 available even if there are thousands of values waiting to be read. The 'available' property should be used as an aide for buffer sizes and the like but should not be taken as an absolute size.

close()
Closes this reader as a source of input. Useful for file readers, but for most others this command does nothing.

compare_to( Object other ).Ternary
This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

The compiler converts: 

  'obj1 < obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == lt'
  'obj1 > obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == gt'
  'obj1 <= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != gt'
  'obj1 >= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != lt'
Implementations of compare_to() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

  if (obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == true
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  else
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
  endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

consume( DataType look_for ).Boolean
Attempts to match and discard the next value from this reader, returning true, or else leaves the next value still pending and returns false.

Returns: 

  "true" if old.peek == look_for
  "false" if old.peek != look_for
Invariant: 
  if (old.peek == look_for) old.skip

create_duplicate().RangeIteratorDescending<<DataType>>
Handles duplicating this iterator when "duplicate(iterator_obj)" is called.

equals( Object other ).Boolean
Returns true if this object is equivalant to another.

The compiler converts 'obj1 == obj2' into 'obj1.equals(obj2)' and 'obj1 != obj2' into 'not obj1.equals(obj2)'.

Implementations of equals() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

 if (obj1.equals(obj2))
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq
   obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
 else
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
 endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation returns true if the this object and the 'other' reference are the same object ('this is other').

has_another().Boolean
Returns "true" if this reader has another value that can be previewed with peek() or read with read().

hash_code().Int32
Returns the hash code of this object, which some classes (like HashTable) rely on. This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

Hash codes are used to quickly test and see if two complex objects are NOT equal. The value returned has no intrinsic meaning, but should conform to the following rules:

1. Two objects that are equivalent should produce the same hash code.

2. If an object's state doesn't change, its hash code shouldn't change either. Internally, this precludes the hash code being based on an object's memory address since Slag doesn't guarantee that an object's address won't change over time.

This has the following implications:

If you override hash_code you should also override equals() and possibly compare_to() and ensure the following contract.

Invariant: 

  if (obj1.hash_code != obj2.hash_code)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

init( DataType first_value, DataType last_value, DataType step_size )
is_exhausted().Boolean
Returns "true" if this reader does not have another value or "false" if it does.

peek().DataType
Returns the next value that will be returned from read(). If there is no next value then a NoNextValueError is thrown.

position( Int32 new_position )
This optional property-write sets the zero-based read position of this reader. When a reader is first created position() returns 0. After a single read() it returns 1, and so on. Readers that don't implement this property will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

position().Int32
This optional property-read returns the zero-based read position of this reader. When a reader is first created position() returns 0. After a single read() it returns 1, and so on.

Readers that don't implement this property will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

read().DataType
Returns the next value from this reader. If (not has_another) then a NoNextValueError is thrown.

read_line().String
Reads and returns the next line of characters up to the next LF or CRLF. The CRLF characters are not part of the return value and are discarded.

Only defined for Reader<<Char>>.

read_list( Int32 size ).DataType[]
Reads the next 'size' number of values and returns them in a list. Requires that there are at least 'size' number of values remaining to be read.

remaining().Int32
This optional property returns how many values remain to be read before the reader is exhausted. Not all readers can implement this property; those that don't will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

rewind()
This optional method resets this reader so that the next read() will return the first value of the series. Readers that don't implement this property will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

skip( [Int32 skip_count] )
Discards exactly the next 'skip_count' number of values rather than reading them. If there are not enough values remaining then a NoNextValueError will be thrown from read().

This program fragment: 

  local var a = reader.read
  reader.read
  reader.read
  local var b = reader.read
is equivalent to this: 
  local var a = reader.read
  reader.skip(2)
  local var b = reader.read

to_List().DataType[]
Creates and returns a list of all the remaining values of this reader.

to_String().String
Returns a string representation of this reader's values.

type_name().String
Returns the true class name of this object. Implemented by the runtime; you should not override this method.

Example: 

  local Object obj = "Hello World"
  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

RangeIteratorGE<<DataType>>

Class RangeIteratorGE<<DataType>>

: Reader<<DataType>>

A reader that steps through a descending range of numbers and includes the last value.

Created by RangeGE objects.

Class Methods
create_duplicate( Object existing ).Object
This factory method initiates object duplication. The compiler transforms the duplicate(obj) command into Object.create_duplicate(obj).

Returns: 

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

Object Variables
last_value : DataType
next_value : DataType
step_size : DataType

Object Methods
available().Int32
Returns the minimum number of additional values that can be immediately read from this reader.

If the reader is exhausted or if it must block to peek or read next then the result will be 0. It is important to note that '0' does not necessarily mean the reader is exhausted.

Many readers will report that they have 1 available even if there are thousands of values waiting to be read. The 'available' property should be used as an aide for buffer sizes and the like but should not be taken as an absolute size.

close()
Closes this reader as a source of input. Useful for file readers, but for most others this command does nothing.

compare_to( Object other ).Ternary
This method is used for ordering (quantitative) comparisons between this object and another.

Returns 'eq' if they're equivalent, 'lt' if this object is "less than" the other, or 'gt' if this object is "greater than" another.

The compiler converts: 

  'obj1 < obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == lt'
  'obj1 > obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) == gt'
  'obj1 <= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != gt'
  'obj1 >= obj2' -> 'obj1.compare_to(obj2) != lt'
Implementations of compare_to() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract: 

  if (obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == true
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  else
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
  endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

consume( DataType look_for ).Boolean
Attempts to match and discard the next value from this reader, returning true, or else leaves the next value still pending and returns false.

Returns: 

  "true" if old.peek == look_for
  "false" if old.peek != look_for
Invariant: 
  if (old.peek == look_for) old.skip

create_duplicate().RangeIteratorGE<<DataType>>
Handles duplicating this iterator when "duplicate(iterator_obj)" is called.

equals( Object other ).Boolean
Returns true if this object is equivalant to another.

The compiler converts 'obj1 == obj2' into 'obj1.equals(obj2)' and 'obj1 != obj2' into 'not obj1.equals(obj2)'.

Implementations of equals() must maintain the following general contract between equals(), compare_to(), and hash_code().

Contract:

   obj1.compare_to(obj2) == eq
   obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
 else
   obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
 endIf
Note that two "equal" objects *must* have the same hash code, but "unequal" objects may or may not have the same hash code.

This default implementation returns true if the this object and the 'other' reference are the same object ('this is other').

has_another().Boolean
Returns "true" if this reader has another value that can be previewed with peek() or read with read().

hash_code().Int32
Returns the hash code of this object, which some classes (like HashTable) rely on. This default implementation throws an UnsupportedMethodError.

1. Two objects that are equivalent should produce the same hash code.

2. If an object's state doesn't change, its hash code shouldn't change either. Internally, this precludes the hash code being based on an object's memory address since Slag doesn't guarantee that an object's address won't change over time.

This has the following implications:

If you override hash_code you should also override equals() and possibly compare_to() and ensure the following contract.

Invariant: 

  if (obj1.hash_code != obj2.hash_code)
    obj1.equals(obj2) == false
    obj1.compare_to(obj2) != eq
  endIf

  if (obj1.equals(obj2))
    obj1.hash_code == obj2.hash_code
  endIf

init( DataType first_value, DataType last_value, DataType step_size )
is_exhausted().Boolean
Returns "true" if this reader does not have another value or "false" if it does.

peek().DataType
Returns the next value that will be returned from read(). If there is no next value then a NoNextValueError is thrown.

position( Int32 new_position )
This optional property-write sets the zero-based read position of this reader. When a reader is first created position() returns 0. After a single read() it returns 1, and so on. Readers that don't implement this property will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

position().Int32
This optional property-read returns the zero-based read position of this reader. When a reader is first created position() returns 0. After a single read() it returns 1, and so on.

Readers that don't implement this property will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

read().DataType
Returns the next value from this reader. If (not has_another) then a NoNextValueError is thrown.

read_line().String
Reads and returns the next line of characters up to the next LF or CRLF. The CRLF characters are not part of the return value and are discarded.

Only defined for Reader<<Char>>.

read_list( Int32 size ).DataType[]
Reads the next 'size' number of values and returns them in a list. Requires that there are at least 'size' number of values remaining to be read.

remaining().Int32
This optional property returns how many values remain to be read before the reader is exhausted. Not all readers can implement this property; those that don't will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

rewind()
This optional method resets this reader so that the next read() will return the first value of the series. Readers that don't implement this property will throw an UnsupportedMethodError when it's accessed.

skip( [Int32 skip_count] )
Discards exactly the next 'skip_count' number of values rather than reading them. If there are not enough values remaining then a NoNextValueError will be thrown from read().

  local var a = reader.read
  reader.read
  reader.read
  local var b = reader.read
is equivalent to this: 
  local var a = reader.read
  reader.skip(2)
  local var b = reader.read

Creates and returns a list of all the remaining values of this reader.

to_String().String
Returns a string representation of this reader's values.

type_name().String
Returns the true class name of this object. Implemented by the runtime; you should not override this method.

Example: 

  local Object obj = "Hello World"
  println( obj.type_name ) #prints: String

: Reader<<DataType>>

A reader that steps through an ascending range of numbers and excludes the last value.

Created by RangeLT objects.

Class Methods

  'null' if 'existing' is null.
  existing.create_duplicate otherwise

is_exhausted().Boolean
Returns "true" if this reader does not have another value or "false" if it does.

Returns the next value that will be returned from read(). If there is no next value then a NoNextValueError is thrown.
